You're wrong. The numbers are the CPI (consumer price index) and they're from the BLS (the Bureau of Labor Statistics). The problem is that the CPI is a shitty measure of inflation, it was never designed for cross-decade inflation comparisons (it is calculated on a monthly and yearly basis), it overestimates inflation, it is higher than other inflationary indicies (as noted), ect.
The IPD is the implicit price deflator, which is another calculation of inflation which is done by the [US Bureau of Economic Analysis,](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bureau_of_Economic_Analysis) which is another US government agency. It is the measure of inflation which is used in the calculation of the increase in productivity rates.
If you don't know that there's multiple inflationary indices which are calculated in different ways and give different results, you don't know enough about the subject matter to argue about it.
None of the inflationary indicies were ever designed for cross-decade comparisons, but people (improperly) apply them for such purposes all the time.
Inflation is not one number. Inflation is calculated by taking equivalent bundles of goods (basically, a set of goods) and looking at their prices in different years. Depending on what your bundle of goods is, you end up with different results.
The problem is that goods don't stay the same over time. A bag of rice is a bag of rice, but a car isn't a car - a 1970 car and a 2017 car are not the same thing. The 2017 car is much better.
This makes doing inflationary calculations extremely difficult, because you're no longer comparing like to like. You need to be comparing equivalent goods, but a good which is much better than another good is not equivalent, it is better. This sort of quality differential is very difficult to deal with.
On a month to month or even a year to year basis, the quality of goods don't change all that much, generally speaking. But on a decade to decade basis, the quality of goods changes considerably in many cases and not at all in others.

It also doesn't include non-income compensation, such as insurance provided by an employer, or payments to pension plans which don't pay off until the future. Notably, non-wage benefits have been increasing over time faster than wages have.

FMJ bullets - full metal jacket bullets - are exactly that - lead rounds surrounded by a lighter, stronger metal, like steel. FMJs are used precisely because *softer* rounds will leave more deposits on the inside of a gun, which is bad if you're firing lots of rounds out of it.
Lead is not used because it is soft, but because it is cheap and *dense*. [The denser a bullet is, the better its penetration is.](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Impact_depth) Penetration is relative to the density of the penetrating object compared to the density of the object it is penetrating.
Denser bullets are also less prone to being affected by outside forces like wind.
This is why depleted uranium is even better - it is even denser (and also has other desirable properties, such as being pyrophoric. On the downside, it is radioactive). You can almost make bullets out of tungsten, which is also super-dense.
Obviously, lead works fine for shooting people, but if you are shooting at materiel, being able to penetrate, say, steel, is useful.

The thing is, while simply humping a tree and regenerating your health leads to odd gameplay at times, the whole "you need to get to cover or you will die" thing isn't actually a bad mechanic. It also depends on the nature of the game; it feels much more natural for shields to regenerate or for a nanosuit (Crysis) to regenerate than it does for a regular old soldier.
The problem that this design was trying to solve was a problem you see in a number of games - basically, if you have a finite amount of resources, the difficulty of any encounter is dependent on the previous ones.
Having a set amount of health that heals before every battle is a good thing because it allows you, as the designer, to know exactly how well off the player will be for every encounter - they can take X many hits. This actually allows you to design more difficult encounters, as the player doesn't get weaker and weaker the further into the mission they go, and allows for you to actually make things harder and harder without making the end of the mission feel ridiculous.
It also allows you to make every encounter a threat - you can die easily on any encounter, rather than having your health worn down and dying on the fifth one because you took too much damage on the first four encounters. Each encounter along the line has more potential for failure, but once they pass it, they're actually past it and they don't have to replay it again because they took one too many hit.

Really, what they *should* do is just to give you back full health at each checkpoint. Basically your health is a resource to make it through an encounter. This leads to each encounter (however long that might be - a single battle, a sequence, whatever) to have the same starting point, and it eliminates the need for health packs.
Plus, presumably, you have some space between encounters, so it feels less weird.

CPI is the highest inflationary index; IPD is lower. None of the inflationary indexes are designed with measuring multi-decade inflation because they simply can't, though. If you look, the CPI is calculated monthly, and they use the CPI across multiple years to calculate inflation.
The way you calculate inflation is by taking bundles of goods and you look at how much that bundle costs at various points in time. The issue is that this doesn't work across large periods of time because the bundles are no longer equivalent.
A bag of rice is a bag of rice, but a 1959 24" black and white TV is not a 2017 24" 1080p flatscreen LCD TV. These sorts of quality improvements make it very hard to do any sort of accurate calculation.
For instance, if you compare the cheapest 2016 automobile to 1990 vehicles with similar features, you quickly find some features simply weren't available in 1990. But if you ignore those features, you see an inflation rate of about 25%. But the CPI puts it much higher than that for cars, as the average price of a new car has almost doubled in that time period.
But the problem is that the price of cars hasn't really doubled, it is that people buy nicer cars. Obviously a nicer car is going to be more expensive, so some of that isn't inflation, it is buying higher quality goods (which isn't inflation).
The CPI's monthly calculations thus are reasonable for trying to look at short-term inflation, but looking at multi-decade inflation, it gets weird and isn't really representative. CPI claims that median income has hardly changed since the mid 1970s, despite the fact that cars have gotten vastly better, appliances have gotten vastly better, AC has become ubiquitous, the Internet is a thing now, cell phones and smart phones are a thing now, houses got 1000+ square feet bigger, and many goods (computers, TVs, microwaves) have stayed constant or gone down in nominal price.
This really just shows that CPI overestimates inflation. Inflation is a real thing, but CPI doesn't appear to be a very good long-term measurement of it.

Bastion's turret mode needs to be reworked
WRITING.TEXT:
Turret mode Bastion is a brick wall.
What is a brick wall, you might ask?
A brick wall is a way of fighting which is very easy to execute, will allow you to win easily if not countered, and is harder to beat than it is to do.
A lot of people know from the good old days that Bastion is seen as very powerful by new players, but players quickly realize how to beat Bastion sitting around in turret mode in the same spot all the time.
This led people to dismiss Bastion as terrible.
The thing is, most players never learned how to play Bastion "for realsies" - they leaned entirely on his turret mode, and failed to actually use his full kit. And why would they? His turret mode seemed so powerful, it is mystifying to players that playing in some way which makes less use of it would make a character stronger. But it does, because learning how to mix things up with Bastion makes him a lot less predictable.
Buffing his turret mode (as Ironclad did) is 100% a mistake. The reason is that it encourages his brick wall strategy. It is a means of making his brick wall strategy harder to bypass - but it doesn't make him fun or interesting to play against.
Brick wall strategies are bad design because they lead to very boring games. Either you can beat the brick wall, and the player using said strategy loses, or you can't beat the brick wall, and the player using said strategy wins. The game entirely hinges on the brick wall, but the gameplay is never really fun - brick walls are repetitive and if the brick wall is bypassed, the player playing the brick wall character doesn't know how to do much else because they're encouraged to play them as a brick wall and don't really learn the rest of the character.
The thing is, most players play Bastion in turret mode all the time because the game seems to be encouraging them to do so, and most players will simply discard him once it becomes clear that this strategy is easily countered. And this makes it hard to [i]fix[/i] Bastion for most of the player base, because most of them will *only* employ his seemingly powerful turret mode, and think any vulnerabilities in it make it "bad", when in fact it is a powerful but situational tool.
There's only one realistic solution: force people to not use turret mode all the time.
Ironclad needs to be nuked. But the turret ability in general needs to be changed - Bastion's turret mode needs to be shifted over to some sort of cooldown ability. Maybe it should just be he goes into that mode and starts spraying bullets, and then leave the mode after his clip is expended automatically. Maybe the mode is time-limited, and then put on cooldown after he exits the mode. Maybe the mode has a limited number of bullets and can't reload, so when you run out, you have to leave the mode.
It doesn't really matter. The point is, the way Bastion was even pre-patch encouraged players to spend all their time in turret mode, sitting around camping in the same spot, and most players will simply not look beyond that unless the game itself forces them to do otherwise.

WRITING.TITLE: Why Ironclad is Broken
WRITING.TEXT:
So, I've been seeing some discussion about Bastion, but I'd like to explain why Ironclad (and indeed, damage reduction in general) is broken in Overwatch.
In Overwatch, there's fairly powerful healing abilities. However, healers do not heal faster than damage dealers deal damage. This is very obvious if you look at Ana/Mercy - Mercy heals 60 damage per second, and Ana 80 per shot. Meanwhile, most of the cast deals much higher damage than that - even Mercy, who is infamously bad offensively, does 100 DPS.
With Ironclad, you take 65% of the damage you would ordinarily take. You might think that 35% damage reduction increases your hit points by 35%, but this is actually wrong - 35% damage reduction increases your hit points by effectively 53%.
The reason why is that instead of taking 100% damage, you're taking 65% damage. 100/65 = 1.53.
A simple example: say there was something that previously killed you in three shots - say, 100 damage per shot. Now you're taking 65 damage per shot.
65 + 65 + 65 = 195 damage. You actually have to take five shots (325 damage) to die now, and you will only just barely die.
Merely increasing someone's hit point total, however, is not enough to be broken. What really makes this broken is the fact that it effectively increases healing by 53% as well.
As a result, mercy is effectively healing you for over 90 damage per second, while Ana is healing you for over 120 damage per shot. And your own self-heal ability, at 75 hp/second, is above what Mercy is doing - and at any time, you can switch over to self-healing.
It is also worth noting that, in Overwatch, damage equals ultimate charge. Someone with effectively 450 hit points, but who only takes 300 damage, is effectively robbing the enemy team of a third of their ult charge relative to their damage.
This is why Ironclad - and indeed, all damage reduction abilities - are so powerful in Overwatch. Nanoboost is so potent in part because, when being pocket healed by an Ana, it is very hard to kill a nanoboosted target at all.
Ironclad, being something which can be turned on at will, is extremely powerful, and it ends up breaking the game in some bad ways.
There's another problem as well - in turret mode, Bastion can only be headshotted from behind - i.e. the non-dangerous side. This is in contrast to every other character in the game, who can be headshotted from every direction. While this in theory makes him weak to being flanked, in practice he can turn around very quickly, and can also simply put himself in a corner or near a wall, where it is very hard to hit him from behind and get the headshot. This further increases the potency of Ironclad, as not only is he massively tougher and massively better healed, but the enemy side loses their primary way of boosting damage against him - scoring headshots.

WRITING.TITLE: What's the longest game you've ever had?
WRITING.TEXT:
[Just had a 22:38 minute match on Lijang Tower.](http://i.imgur.com/B429zSm.jpg)
It wasn't too bad at first. Sure, the first round went to 99% on both sides... we won the second round... lost the third round marginally...
Then the fourth round was this insanely terrible overtime where we got to 99%, then the other team capped the point in OT and got to 99%, and then we just kept on zerging the point from our spawn over and over and over again. Managed to do so for long enough for the overtime bar to almost instantly go to zero if we left the point... but we managed to finally win it back!
At which point the *other* team started jumping on the point, stalling as long as possible, and I'm just laughing to myself about how they were worried about this happening on every other map type...
I think the D. Vas on each team got their ult up three times apiece during overtime.
Then the fifth round also had some overtime, though it was a lot more one-sided and they didn't keep the point for that long.

WRITING.TITLE: Damage is not defined by role in Overwatch
WRITING.TEXT:
So, I see this mistake from time to time amongst people who don't really understand Overwatch, and I think it is vitally important to understand:
*All* heroes in Overwatch deal damage.
A lot of people have simplified "Offense and defense" into DPS. I understand that a lot of people come from MMO backgrounds, as well as from MOBAs, but the reality is that the idea of "DPS" is deeply flawed.
In Overwatch, *everyone* deals damage, because the point of the game is to kill the enemy team and take the objectives, and almost all of the characters are designed to be able to proactively do so.
Seven characters can deal over 200 damage with either their basic attack or a basic ability. Three of them (Torbjorn, Widowmaker, and Hanzo) are Defense. One of them (Reaper) is offense. Two of them (Reinhardt and Roadhog) are tanks. One of them (Zenyatta) is support.
And yet, I see people acting like it is somehow surprising that tanks and supports deal lots of damage.
Indeed, if you look at the characters who deal the highest "damage per second" in the game in their effective ranges, they're not at all confined to a single role. Indeed, members of all four roles have high and low "damage per second".
The roles are not, in fact, about damage. They're about your function on the team.
Offense heroes are mostly defined by their mobility and consequently apply pressure to a selected point; indeed, the only offense hero whose mobility isn't all that great is McCree, making him something of an outlier, though his range and high accuracy does help him apply pressure, and his stun can help break up a block of enemies. No one doubts Genji's place amongst these heroes, even though his "damage per second" is rather lackluster.
The defense characters are mostly defined by what Blizzard felt was their ability to hold position and make it dangerous to enter an area; all of them but Mei are highly effective at laying down damage from long range, with Mei instead being more of a controller type character, a character who applies debuffs and modifies the battlefield - this is closest to a defensive ability, so she got thrown in with the defense characters, even though she plays very differently from them. Many of these characters boast very high damage, including Bastion, who has the highest damage of any character in the game - but Mei has quite poor damage, and is one of the few characters who cannot kill you within a single second even with headshots.
Tanks are defined by their ability to lead a team into battle, hold points, toughness, and area denial - they are dangerous to stand close to, and protect their allies from harm both directly (with barriers and bubbles and similar things) and indirectly, by making it dangerous to stand close to them and therefore, defending their more frail allies by their mere presence by deterring foes from hanging around them.
Support characters are mostly defined by having healing abilities and buffing their team, as well as debuffing their enemies. Symmetra is the real outlier there - she is more of a defense character, like Torbjorn - but is in there because of her ability to generate shields and because her teleporter has the effect of reducing a team's down time (in a sort of weird pseudo-rezzing way). While some of these characters have poor damage output, Zenyatta has very high damage output, and his discord orbs raise not only his own damage output, but that of his entire team. But no one would doubt that he is a healer.
Dealing damage is part of a character's kit, but it is not confined to any particular role, nor does it define it. What really defines a character's role on a team is not their damage output, but what they contribute to a team. And all characters deal damage - indeed, they must, so that they can contribute to a team and help them win.
The idea that one particular role or another has a monopoly on damage is false. They don't. That isn't how the game is designed. Damage is an important part of every character's kit, but it doesn't define role - role is defined by how the character contributes to their team.

DPS is misleading - damage lands faster than it appears
WRITING.TEXT:
Who kills you faster with their primary weapon: McCree or Soldier 76?
The most obvious answer is to look at DPS. McCree does 70 damage per shot with a body shot, and shoots twice per second, for 140 DPS. Soldier 76 does 20 damage per shot, and fires 8.8 shots per second, for 176 DPS.
Who kills you first with nothing but body shots?
Hint: it isn't Soldier 76.
The reason why is fairly simple if you think about how much damage has been done over time. McCree does 70 damage at time = 0. Soldier 76 does 20. At half a second, McCree has done 140 damage. And at 1 second, McCree has done 210 damage.
Soldier 76, meanwhile, will have only done 180 damage by that point, having fired off 9 shots.
This is even more obvious if you compare them when they land headshots half the time. McCree does 140 damage with a headshot, Soldier 76 does 40. McCree will kill you after just two shots - which he can get off in half a second. Soldier 76, even if he lands half of his shots as headshots, will take seven shots to kill you.
Characters who fire a small number of high damage shots per second deal damage much sooner than characters who fire a large number of low damage shots per second, even if the low-damage character has the same DPS.
Junkrat fires 1.66 shots per second, or a shot per 40 frames at 60 FPS. His shots do 120 damage on a direct hit, meaning that if Junkrat hits you with two direct shots, you're going to die on frame 40 + travel time for his projectile - or in a bit more than 2/3rds of a second.
Reinhardt does 75 damage per swing. His first swing comes out at 0 seconds, his second swing at 1 second, and his third swing at 2 seconds - meaning that if you are in close quarters with Rein, he isn't killing you in three seconds (as you might suspect from his 75 DPS), he's actually killing you in two seconds.
While DPS can be an important number to know, remember that it can be very misleading - *when* over the course of that second damage is done is very important to know.
